sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with no solutions.
message_1:
Consider the system of linear equations: 

2x + 3y = 10

4x + 6y = 20

Does this system have a solution? If not, why?
message_2:
This system of linear equations does not have a unique solution. The reason is that the two equations are not independent; they are multiples of each other. 

To see this, notice that the second equation can be obtained by multiplying the first equation by 2:

2 * (2x + 3y) = 2 * 10
4x + 6y = 20

Since the two equations are essentially the same, they represent the same line in the xy-plane. Therefore, there are infinitely many solutions, as any point on the line defined by the equation 2x + 3y = 10 will satisfy both equations.
